issues.text: whether the order of detention passed against, and served on the petitioner Rameshwar Shaw while he was in jail custody is justified by section 3(1) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950

issues.text: whether the detention of the petitioner is justified by the provisions of s. 3(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg for the petitioner has challenged validity of the petitioners detention on several grounds. He contends that the detention of the petitioner is not justified by the provisions of s. 3 1  of the Act and as such is invalid.

arguments.claim: District Magistrate acted outside powers under s.3(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we see no escape from the conclusion that the detention of the petitioner in the circumstances of this case, is not justified by s. 3(1)(a) and is outside its purview.

holdings.text: The first contention raised by Mr. Garg is well-founded; the detention of the petitioner is not justified by s. 3(1)(a) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have come to the conclusion that the first contention raised by Mr. Garg is well-founded, we do not propose to consider the merits of the other arguments urged by him in support of his petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner was in jail custody when detention order served; no freedom to act prejudicially, so subjective satisfaction under s.3(1)(a) lacks basis as scheme postulates freedom of action.

holdings.text: A detention order under s.3(1)(a) postulates that the person sought to be detained must have freedom to act prejudicially at the time the order is brought into force; absent if already in jail custody without imminent release.

anchor.surface_text: The argument which Mr. Garg has urged before us is that if a person is already under detention, it would not be reasonably possible for the appropriate authority to satisfy himself that the detention of such a person is necessary in order to prevent him from acting in any prejudicial manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction of s.3(1)(a): order to prevent prejudicial activity requires freedom of action; illogical if person locked in jail.

holdings.text: The detention of the petitioner is not justified by s.3(1)(a) and is outside its purview; District Magistrate acted outside powers conferred by s.3(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we see no escape from the conclusion that the detention of the petitioner in the circumstances of this case, is not justified by s. 3(1)(a) and is outside its purview. The District Magistrate, Burdwan who ordered the detention of the detenu acted outside his powers conferred on him by s. 3(1)(a)

holdings.reasoning_summary: No rational basis for satisfaction of necessity to detain to prevent prejudicial acts when petitioner already in custody; basis of order absent.

holdings.text: The petition succeeds and the order of detention passed on February 9, 1963 is set aside.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Operative order based on invalidity under s.3(1)(a).

holdings.text: As an abstract proposition, s.3(1)(a) does not preclude passing a detention order against a person already in detention or jail custody.

anchor.surface_text: As an abstract proposition of law, there may not be any doubt that s. 3(1)(a) does not preclude the authority from passing an order of detention against a person whilst he is in detention or in jail

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from facts; possible if proximate to release (e.g., short term, known release).

holdings.text: A person in jail custody cannot be served with a detention order while in such custody, as no freedom to act prejudicially postulated.

anchor.surface_text: The question which still remains to be considered is can a person in jail custody, like the petitioner, be served with an order of detention whilst he is in such custody? ... The satisfaction that it is necessary to detain a person for the purpose of preventing him from acting in a prejudicial manner is thus the basis of the order under s. 3(1)(a) , and this basis is clearly absent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Service brings order into force; requires freedom at that point, absent in custody.

holdings.text: Material provisions of the Act must be strictly construed and safeguards liberally interpreted.

anchor.surface_text: It is hardly necessary to emphasise that since the Act authorises the preventive detention of citizens without a trial, the material provisions of the Act must be strictly construed and all safeguards which the Act has deliberately provided for the protection of citizens must be liberally interpreted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle for preventive detention laws.

holdings.text: Subjective satisfaction under s.3(1)(a) is not justiciable except for irrelevance, vagueness of grounds, or mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the satisfaction of the detaining authority to which s. 3(1)(a) refers is his subjective satisfaction, and so is not justiciable. ... It is only in this incidental manner and in support of the plea of mala fides that this question can become justiciable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents like State of Bombay v. Atma Ram; limits on review.

holdings.text: Past conduct or antecedent history for detention must ordinarily be proximate in time and rationally connected to future prejudicial activity.

anchor.surface_text: the past conduct or antecedent history of the person on which the authority purports to act, should ordinarily be proximate in point of time and should have a rational connection with the conclusion that the detention of the person is necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Ujagar Singh v. State of Punjab; no inflexible test, case-by-case.

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya 1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya 1 . There is also numberdoubt that if any of the grounds furnished to the detenu are found to be irrelevant while companysidering the application of clauses  i  to  iii  of s. 3 1   a  and in that sense are foreign to the Act, the satisfaction of the detaining authority on which the order of detention is based is open to challenge and the detention order liable to be quashed.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya
precedents.cited_proposition: the satisfaction contemplated by section 3(1)(a) is subjective and not justiciable; reasonableness or adequacy of material cannot be questioned in court

precedents.citation: Ujagar Singh v. The State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Ujagar Singh v. The State of Punjab and jagjit Singh -v. The State of Punjab 1  that the past companyduct or antecedent history of a person can be taken into account in making a detention order, and as a matter of fact, it is largely from prior events showing tendencies or inclinations of a man that an inference companyld be drawn whether he is likely even in the future to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

precedents.case_name: Ujagar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: past conduct or antecedent history of a person can be taken into account in making a detention order

precedents.citation: jagjit Singh -v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: jagjit Singh -v. The State of Punjab 1  that the past companyduct or antecedent history of a person can be taken into account in making a detention order, and as a matter of fact, it is largely from prior events showing tendencies or inclinations of a man that an inference companyld be drawn whether he is likely even in the future to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. In this companynection, it is, however, necessary to bear in mind that the past companyduct or antecedent history of the person on which the authority purports to act, should ordinarily be proximate in point of time and should have a rational companynection with the companyclusion that the detention of the person is necessary.

precedents.case_name: Jagjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: past conduct or antecedent history of a person can be taken into account in making a detention order

anchor.surface_text: Basanta Chandra Ghose v. Emperor 1 . In that case the main question which arose for the decision of the Court was, however, of a different character. It was urged on behalf of the detenu before the Court that where an earlier order of detention passed against him was held to be defective, though on formal grounds, it was number open to the authority to pass a subsequent order of detention against him on the same grounds as had been set out in support of the earlier order.

precedents.cited_proposition: no bar to passing detention order against a person already under detention

precedents.citation: Labaram Deka Barua Anr. v. The State 1

anchor.surface_text: Labaram Deka Barua Anr. v. The State  1 , and Haridas Deka v. State  2 . Mr. Sen has, however, relied on the decision of the Assam High Court in Sahadat Ali v. The State of Assam Ors. 3 . In that case it appeared that the Government had decided in public interest to abandon the prosecution which was pending against the detenu.

precedents.case_name: Labaram Deka Barua & Anr. v. State
precedents.cited_proposition: same view on scope of s.3(1)(a) regarding detention of person already in custody

anchor.surface_text: Haridas Deka v. State  2 . Mr. Sen has, however, relied on the decision of the Assam High Court in Sahadat Ali v. The State of Assam Ors. 3 . In that case it appeared that the Government had decided in public interest to abandon the prosecution which was pending against the detenu. The said decision was duly companyveyed to the police and so, the police reported under section 173 of the Criminal Procedure Code for the release of the detenu.

precedents.cited_proposition: same view on scope of s.3(1)(a) regarding detention of person already in custody

precedents.citation: Sahadat Ali v. The State of Assam Ors. 3

anchor.surface_text: Sahadat Ali v. The State of Assam Ors. 3 . In that case it appeared that the Government had decided in public interest to abandon the prosecution which was pending against the detenu. The said decision was duly companyveyed to the police and so, the police reported under section 173 of the Criminal Procedure Code for the release of the detenu. In anticipation of this release, the order of detention was passed against him and it was served on him after he was ac- tually released.

precedents.case_name: Sahadat Ali v. State of Assam & Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: detention order valid if served after anticipated release despite prior custody

anchor.surface_text: Since we have come to the conclusion that the first contention raised by Mr. Garg is well-founded, we do not propose to consider the merits of the other arguments urged by him in support of his petition.
The result is, the petition succeeds and the order of detention passed against the petitioner by the District Ma- gistrate, Burdwan, on the 9th February, 1963, is set aside.

edges.explanation: The general principle in h2 that detention under s.3(1)(a) postulates freedom at enforcement (absent if already detained) supports the specific conclusion in h3 that the petitioner's detention is invalid under that section.

Holding h2 sets out the principle that a detention order under s.3(1)(a) requires the detainee to have freedom to act prejudicially when the order is enforced, which is absent if already in custody, directly addressing whether such an order served in jail custody is justified.

anchor.surface_text: The argument which Mr. Garg has urged before us is that if a person is already under detention, it would not be reasonably possible for the appropriate authority to satisfy himself that the detention of such a person is necessary in order to prevent him from acting in any prejudicial manner.
The result is, the petition succeeds and the order of detention passed against the petitioner by the District Ma- gistrate, Burdwan, on the 9th February, 1963, is set aside.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 directly concludes that the petitioner's detention is not justified by s.3(1)(a) and outside its purview, resolving the issue of whether the order served in jail custody is justified.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we see no escape from the conclusion that the detention of the petitioner in the circumstances of this case, is not justified by s. 3(1)(a) and is outside its purview. The District Magistrate, Burdwan who ordered the detention of the detenu acted outside his powers conferred on him by s. 3(1)(a)
The result is, the petition succeeds and the order of detention passed against the petitioner by the District Ma- gistrate, Burdwan, on the 9th February, 1963, is set aside.
The result is, the petition succeeds and the order of detention passed against the petitioner by the District Ma- gistrate, Burdwan, on the 9th February, 1963, is set aside.
As an abstract proposition of law, there may not be any doubt that s. 3(1)(a) does not preclude the authority from passing an order of detention against a person whilst he is in detention or in jail

The question which still remains to be considered is can a person in jail custody, like the petitioner, be served with an order of detention whilst he is in such custody? ... The satisfaction that it is necessary to detain a person for the purpose of preventing him from acting in a prejudicial manner is thus the basis of the order under s. 3(1)(a) , and this basis is clearly absent
The result is, the petition succeeds and the order of detention passed against the petitioner by the District Ma- gistrate, Burdwan, on the 9th February, 1963, is set aside.
